James in born
Won a scholarship to attend Queen's Royal College. After graduation, he worked as a school teacher

Meets Leon Trotsky. For a transcript of their interview, see CLR James Papers, Box 12 Folder 15. He returns via bus through the southern United States
Stays for two days to catch the S.S. Tegucigalpa to New Orleans ( six day journey)
Stays for three days before taking a bus to New York, stopping in Memphis on the way
Based in New York
James is in D.C. for the weekend on party work

Goes for convention in Chicago but too ill to attend

Stays in Reno for several months to secure his divorce from Juanita James, his first wife

Interned at Ellis Island, where he writes Mariners, Renegades, and Castaways. James was there for six months.
Returns to London following deportation from U.S.

Based in London
Placed under house arrest for six weeks by Eric Williams. Before this, he is apparently following the West Indies cricket tour
Based in London
Worcester says James returned in the "summer" of 1965. He leaves a few weeks following the 1966 election

column4: Worcester 169; CLR James Papers Box 10 Folder 16, CLR James Papers Box 10 Folder 8, Austin 15
column8: Delivers the lecture "The Making of the Caribbean Peoples" at the Second Conference on West Indian Affairs. The date is given as "summer." Also gives the lecture "Existentialism and Marxism." Worcester lists this lecture as having taken place in London, but Austin has correspondence demonstrating that it was in Montreal
Returns to Trinidad for the elections, where his Workers' and Farmers' Party is defeated

column4: CLR James Papers Box 4 Folder 3, Austin 16
column8: Delivers a series of public and private lectures in Montreal on the invitation of the Caribbean Conference Committee and the C.L.R. James Study Circle. These lectures are collected in David Austin's You Don't Play With Revolution

column4: CLR James Papers Box 4 Folder 3, Austin 277
column8: Lecture tour that includes stop in Detroit. First time re-entering the U.S. after being expelled in 1953
Lecture tour of Canada
Correspondence during this time period is from London
Attended 1968 Cultural Congress in Havana. Details and a summary of his paper available in Andrew Salkey's Havana Journal. Aimé Césaire and René Depestre attended his 67th birthday party
Exact dates ambiguous. Tour also included Isle of Pines, Pinar del Rio, Matanzas, Las Villas, and Camagüey
